phaseDescriptions.menstrual:
The menstrual cycle starts on the first day of your period and ends the day before your next period begins.

The period is when the lining of the uterus sheds and leaves the body through vaginal bleeding. The period usually lasts from 3 to 7 days.
phaseDescriptions.follicular: The follicular phase is the first part of the menstrual cycle, and starts on the first day of your period (so there is some overlap with the menstrual phase) and ends with ovulation (when one of your ovaries releases an egg).
phaseDescriptions.ovulatory:
Ovulation is the release of an egg from your ovary. This is the peak fertility window, and it typically occurs about 12 to 16 days before the next menstrual period begins. For an average 28-day cycle, this is around day 14.

The chance to conceive is highest during this phase. The egg can live for about 24 hours once released.
phaseDescriptions.luteal:
This phase begins immediately after ovulation and lasts until the first day of the next period. It typically runs about 12‚Äì14 days.

During this time, the body prepares for a potential pregnancy by thickening the uterine lining. If fertilization does not occur, hormone levels drop and menstruation begins.

If your expected period date has passed and bleeding hasn't started yet, your luteal phase is simply continuing beyond its usual length.

pregnancyChanceDescriptions.high: This is your fertile window when conception is most likely to occur. Ovulation typically happens during this time.
pregnancyChanceDescriptions.medium: There is a moderate chance of conception during this time as you approach or move away from your fertile window.
pregnancyChanceDescriptions.low:
Conception is less likely during this time. The chance of getting pregnant increases during ovulation and the fertile days around it.

While chances may vary, you can conceive on any day of your cycle. If you don't want to get pregnant, it's best to use contraception every time you have sex.

menstrual.note: You‚Äôll probably find that if you get period pains, they‚Äôll be at their worst in the beginning of your menstrual cycle.

follicular.intro: Since the follicular phase begins with menstruation, you'll likely experience typical period symptoms such as:
follicular.note: As your period ends and estrogen begins rising, you may feel more energized, motivated and socially confident. Rising estrogen can also improve skin appearance for some people.

items: Your sense of smell may become sharper

luteal.intro: The change in the level of progesterone as you approach your period may cause symptoms of PMS (pre-menstrual syndrome), such as:
luteal.note: These PMS symptoms typically worsen as your period approaches.

cycleLength.title: Understanding your cycle
cycleLength.definitionText: is counted from the first day of one period to the first day of the next period.

normalRange.title: Normal range
normalRange.acogName: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG)¬π
normalRange.acogSuffix: , a normal menstrual cycle typically lasts between
normalRange.variation: Most people have cycles that vary by a few days each month, which is completely normal.

irregular.title: Irregular cycles
irregular.daysRange: shorter than 21 days or longer than 35 days
irregular.descriptionSuffix: and can be caused by a variety of reasons, such as:

causes.weight: Significant weight change or intense exercise

irregular.dataNote: can cause Bluma to indicate an abnormal cycle length. Most often, this is the result of forget to log period. Tracking your cycles for at least 3-6 months will help establish a pattern.

seeDoctor.title: When to see a doctor?
seeDoctor.description: If your cycles are frequently abnormal in length, or/and accompanied by other concerning symptoms, it's best to talk to your health care provider. They can help you figure out the cause and suggest treatment, if necessary.

cycleLength.disclaimer: Bluma is not a diagnostic tool. The information from Bluma does not replace advice from a health care provider. Always seek the advice of your doctor or other qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding your cycle.

references.title: References
references.acog: 1. Diagnosis of Abnormal Uterine Bleeding in Reproductive-Aged Women. Practice Bulletin. Number 128, July 2012. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

periodLength.title: Understanding your period
periodLength.definitionText: is counted from the first until the last day of menstrual bleeding of any volume.

normal.title: Normal period length
normal.acogName: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG)¬π
normal.acogSuffix: , a normal period length typically lasts between
normal.variation: Period length can vary from cycle to cycle, which is completely normal.

irregular.title: Irregular periods
irregular.description: Irregular periods (shorter than 2 days or longer than 7 days) might be caused by lifestyle changes, medication, stress, travel, and a few other factors that can affect hormone levels.
irregular.dataNote: could be the reason your period length is labeled prolonged or shortened. You can always correct any event of your cycle retrospectively on the calendar menu.

seeDoctor.title: When to see a doctor?
seeDoctor.description: If your period length is frequently abnormal in length, or/and accompanied by other concerning symptoms, it's best to talk to your health care provider. They can help you figure out the cause and suggest treatment, if necessary.

periodLength.disclaimer: Bluma is not a diagnostic tool. The information from Bluma does not replace advice from a health care provider. Always seek the advice of your doctor or other qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding your cycle.

references.title: References
references.acog: 1. Your First Period. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. FAQ for patients.

whatMeans.title: What does a late period mean?
whatMeans.description:
A period is generally considered late when it's more than 7 days past your expected date. Going 6 weeks without a period is called a missed period.

This can and does happen, and there are many possible reasons beyond pregnancy:

causes: Weight changes and low energy intake
Hormonal contraception (pills, injections, implants, hormonal IUDs, and some emergency contraception)
Perimenopause (the years leading up to menopause)
Sudden changes in routine or sleep (shift work, jet lag)
Significant diet changes or poor nutrition
Medications (e.g. antipsychotics, antidepressants, anti-epileptics, chemotherapy drugs)

seeDoctor.title: When to see a doctor
seeDoctor.description: If your period is repeatedly more than about a week late, or you have missed two or three in a row (and pregnancy is ruled out), it is important to see a healthcare professional so they can check for these underlying causes and tailor advice to you.

whatToDo.title: What you can do
whatToDo.pregnancy: Take a pregnancy test if there's any possibility
whatToDo.stress: Manage stress through meditation, exercise, or therapy
whatToDo.weight: Maintain a healthy weight for your body
whatToDo.track: Track your cycles to identify patterns
whatToDo.patience: Be patient, cycles can naturally vary by a few days each month, so occasional lateness is normal.

latePeriod.disclaimer: Bluma is not a diagnostic tool. The information from Bluma does not replace advice from a health care provider. Always seek the advice of your doctor or other qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding your cycle.

references.title: References
references.ucla: 2. Missed your period but not pregnant? 7 possible causes. UCLA Health. January 3, 2024. https://www.uclahealth.org/news/article/missed-your-period-not-pregnant-7-possible-causes-2

nextPeriod.title: Next period prediction
nextPeriod.description: Your next period is predicted by adding your average cycle length to the start date of your most recent period.

cycleLengthCalc.title: Cycle length calculation
cycleLengthCalc.description: Bluma calculates your average cycle length using a weighted average of your last 6 cycles, a commonly used approach in cycle tracking.
cycleLengthCalc.weighting: Recent cycles have more influence on predictions than older ones. For example, most recent cycle: 100%, second most recent: 80%, third most recent: 60%, and so on.

ovulation.title: Ovulation & fertility window
ovulation.description: Ovulation generally occurs around the 14th day of a 28-day menstrual cycle. The exact timing depends on cycle length, typically falling in the middle of the cycle, though it can vary for individuals with shorter or longer cycles. Your fertile window includes:
ovulation.fertileWindow:
‚Ä¢ 5 days before ovulation
‚Ä¢ Ovulation day
‚Ä¢ 1 day after ovulation

To predict ovulation and fertile window, Bluma relies on the cycle data you log, including your cycle length and your period dates.

If you logged your period in Bluma for the first time or have logged a few periods, the app will use average values to predict your fertile days during cycle. Because this is less accurate, you're likely to see more fertile days and a wider fertile window.

accuracy.title: Accuracy improves over time
accuracy.description: The more you log your period dates, the more accurate the predictions become. With 3+ cycles, Bluma can provide better predictions based on your patterns.

privacy.title: Privacy first
privacy.description: All calculations happen locally on your device. Your period data never leaves your phone and is never shared with anyone.

prediction.disclaimerSuffix: : These are predictions based on your historical data. Every body is different, and cycles can vary naturally.
